POS 1 7,11

DLG a
A crystal perfume bottle, catalogue number 315.

DLG b
A necklace made from shells. Catalogue number 553.

DLG c
The imprint of the string is still visible in the clay, detailed photographs will be taken.

DLG g
A round bronze pin, this would have kept a cloak fastened. Catalong number 356

DLG h
A gold ring made from plaited strands. Catalogue Number 442.

DLG d
This blade is very delicate now, it must be removed with the greatest of care.

DLG e
A short steel sword. Catalogue number 154

DLG f
The wooden handle has long since rotted away.

DLG i
Both pagan and Christian Anglo-Saxons buried their dead with grave goods.

DLG j
Amongst the earlier Anglo-Saxons who adhered to pagan beliefs,

DLG k
such goods accompanied both inhumed and cremated remains.

DLG l
In some cases, animal skulls, particularly oxen but also pig, were buried in human graves, a practice also found in Roman Britain.

DLG m
Howard WIlliams argued that grave goods carried mnemonic significance in Early Medieval society.

DLG r
Grave goods can inform archaeologists about cultural connections and trade;

DLG p
 for instance, at Buckland cemetery near Dover, Kent, over half of the brooches buried as grave goods were imports from continental Europe

DLG t
illustrating the connections between the Kingdom of Kent and the Frankish area.

END 0


END undefined
Lara Croft went on to get a distinction for her masters degree in archaeology, she is now working towards a PHD on the  effects of colonialism on Ancient Egyptian excavation site management.
